entry.title: RC - day 36
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • started the week right with experimental check-in group
  • paired with Ivan on improving blog loading
  • worked on an app concept with Alicia, Isla and Juan
  • took part in OpenGL workshop
  • discussed my next portfolio + blog steps with Jeni
  • had some inspiration for growing as a programmer

The experimental check-in group is about accountability, so we’ve started the week with assigning each other a person to help us and someone we could help with their work. I got a lot of support from Jeni on my writing and discussed Aissam’s up with him (though I don’t feel I’ve helped him much).

We’ve also done the initial planning for our problem-tracking app - we’re going to set it up in Django and do the initial functionality in plain HTML + CSS, to be further improved with proper JS (we might even try a JS framework, though it seems like a lot of work for a tiny app).

Other than that, the OpenGL workshop brought some inspiration, but I’m afraid I don’t have enough time for it know, with all the career- and CS-focused tasks ahead. I have some ideas on my next career steps, but I need to clarify and commit to them.

entry.title: RC - day 35
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • got some more time off
  • finally went to Times Square
  • wrote my first “professional” blog post

Today was mostly about relaxing by playing with kittens, walking and organising. There was nearly nobody at RC, which meant I got a lot of space to focus.

entry.title: The First 20 Hours
entry.content:
I have recently reread The First 20 Hours: How To Learn Anything… Fast! by Josh Kaufman - a light book with some helpful insights on acquiring new skills. As I have so much to learn and so little time (or at least so is my perception), the concept of spending just 20 hours on something and going from knowing nothing to performing noticeably well is appealing.

One needs to forget the notion of 10.000 hours needed to master a skill. That is not to say that practicing for about 5 years as a full-time job won’t help in acquiring and mastering a skill, it’s simply that most of us don’t need to be experts in every field. Sometimes just the basic skill can get a long way.

Some of the concepts presented in the book reminded me of well-known economic ideas, among others:

  • the law of diminishing returns - the more you learn, the less noticeable your progress (just as well as eating more and more chocolate won’t bring noticeable difference after the first half of the bar)

  • Pareto principle - 20% of efforts bring 80% of returns (but those efforts have to be directed and deliberate)

  • Parkinson’s law - work will fill out all the time available (so shorter deadlines can be more productive)

Merely understanding and noticing these rules may not be enough to overcome them, so Josh goes on to present actionable steps for learning any skill. By ‘any skill’ he means ‘any skill that is important to you’. The first step is to choose a lovable subject and concentrate on one project at a time.

Secondly, one needs to define a target performance. What does it mean for you to learn a skill? If you were to learn a language, do you want to be a communicative tourist during your summer holidays or have never-ending philosophical disputes? Do you want to play guitar at a campfire or be a rock star? Josh advices that it’s better to start small - when you can understand the basic concepts and perform simple tasks, you can then move on to more sophisticated notions. In order to be a rock star, you need to know how a guitar produces the sounds and how to strum it.

In order to take the first steps, one can apply the rules of rapid skill acquisition, mainly:

  • deconstructing the desired skill into smallest possible subskills

  • learning about each subskill to practice intelligently and self-correct based on fast feedback loops

  • removing barriers to learning
    • physical - acquiring the right tools (e.g. guitar, books) and setting aside time for practice (e.g. every day for 45 minutes)
    • mental and emotional - setting oneself in a can-do mindset (e.g. I can learn this concept for the next 20 minutes)
  • practicing mindfully and deliberately

Constraining oneself further with practicing for just 20 hours or until the desired target performance is reached helps with avoiding the Parkinson’s law trap. Also, short-term results are usually the most rapid ones, as the function of skill to time is most steep at the very start. Hence one can get pretty good quickly and base motivation for their next steps on the already achieved success.

Concentrating on one skill for a short time has also the advantage of testing the idea. Do I really want to speak Spanish, or is it just something I feel I need to know? Is this something I want to spend more time on? Sometimes one can’t know their own preferences until they’ve properly tested their presumptions. After a short experiment, there is no harm in deciding not to follow up on it.

In his book, Josh goes on to describe how he acquired six new skills over the course of a year:

  • setting up a daily yoga routine

  • basic programming and building two applications

  • touch typing in Colemak

  • playing Go

  • playing ukulele

  • windsurfing

As I don’t want to spoil the book, I’ll briefly describe the ukulele-playing chapter.

How would one go about it?

  1. Obtaining an ukulele and other necessary equipment seems like a good start.

  2. Learning how it works (parts of the instrument, where does the sound come from etc.).

  3. Focusing on learning four most common chords (they say you can play most pop songs with just G, D, Em and C).

  4. When one can play the chords without looking, practicing until they can play them without thinking.

  5. Beginning to learn songs by humming along, then adding lyrics.

  6. Experimenting, e.g. learning fingerpicking and new chords.

  7. Never graduating.

You can watch Josh’s talk about these concepts or buy his book. Other resources you might find useful:

  • The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg, a book on understanding habits and some ideas on how to change them

  • Learning How to Learn a free MOOC on the basic concepts of learning and the inner workings of the mind

  • Become a Superlearner a relatively cheap course focusing on rapid learning and memory techniques, with a lot of emphasis on speed reading

  • Lifehacker a website with daily ideas on various topics, in the spirit of lifehacking

  • xkcd a delightful comic on life and science by Randall Munroe (check out his wonderful books)

  • Saturday Morning Breakfast Cereal a philosophical and satirical web comic by Zach Weinersmith

Happy learning!
entry.summary: I have recently reread The First 20 Hours: How To Learn Anything… Fast! by Josh Kaufman - a light book with some helpful insights on acquiring new skills. As I have so much to learn and so little time (or at least so is my perception), the concept of spending just 20 hours on something and going from knowing nothing to performing noticeably well is appealing.

entry.title: RC - day 34
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • watching Objectified
  • awesome women’s night at RC

Cats, books and Stranger Things kept me entertained most of the day. The kitties are playful and curious, constantly nagging me for attention. Focusing was not an easy task.

We’ve also had a great women’s night at RC, thanks to Isla & Kaylyn (and RC staff, of course), discussing some of our experiences and developing strategies and actionable solutions to common problems.

I especially loved two simple strategies presented by Alicia:

  • inappropriate comment

    • ask the person to repeat their comment, to avoid ambiguity (e.g. what did you say? what do you mean by that? excuse me?)
    • label the comment/language (e.g. that’s ignorant/sexist/dismissive), not the person
    • get back to work (after all, you are paid to work and hopefully so is the other person)

  • unwelcome behaviour

    Instead of reacting on the spot, it’s best to talk in person, e.g. “I feel like you interrupt me, have you noticed?” - that’s a simple yes or no question and both answers are great!

    1. yes - “good! please don’t do that again”
    2. no - “no problem, how about I just let you know if I notice it again?” (opening for further improvement)

It is much easier to react and solve problems when we can name them. And we don’t feel crazy, because it’s not “just you” or “an incident” - it’s something many women experience daily.

We also came up with an idea for an app to register unwanted behaviours and easily visualise them, which I hope to mob code with my awesome RC friends over the next week.

I’m rarely in all women environments and it was freeing to experience that. Without men around we behave differently, focusing on communication rather than perceptions.

entry.title: RC - day 33
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • architectural whiteboarding
  • mob coding with brownie shots
  • committing the weekend to focus

I was worried the whiteboarding will not go well, as I’ve never done it before and didn’t feel I know enough to answer any questions. I’ve read up on anything I could find on the topic and headed to Turing a bit lightheaded.

The flaw in my reasoning was forgetting that this was RC and the purpose is to learn, not stress. I’ve spent 3 wonderful hours with Bert, Alicia, Ivan and James, going through 5 questions altogether. When we finished I felt a bit dizzy from all the problem solving.

Afterwards, Joe, Cihan and me followed through with the idea of mob coding with enhanced brownies. A few rounds of Malibu with milk later and full of chocolate, we’ve managed to solve a fairly simple graph problem.

I couldn’t stay for the debugging, as today my cat sitting responsibilities started. Both fluffs are keen to play and curious, chasing after anything that moves (even if it doesn’t). Danielle and David’s apartment is full of books on programming and art, with even more fiction, especially of the sf nature. With cats, books and loads of space, it feels like a perfect focused getaway.

entry.title: RC - day 32
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • sleeping in to destress
  • meditating
  • reading up for Friday interview prep
  • had a presentation on learning new skills

Thursday was a presentation day. We’ve had 8 usual evening presentations and 12 non-technical talks, amounting to three hours of learning something new every 5 to 10 minutes.

Three technical talks I enjoyed most were:

  • Satabdi’s Noteranger app for searching her notes
  • Andrea’s great idea for visualising art by style (I’d love to learn more about convolutional neural networks)
  • Marf’s coverage of her two-week spree of exclusively pairing made me want to pair more

The non-technical talks were so diverse it’s really hard to pick favourites, but some of them resonated with me:

  • Alicia’s talk on media literacy and porn consumption was marvelous, I hope she shares her thesis with us (I’ve only managed to find the title Media Literacy for Pornography: Assessing the Impact of an Experimental Curriculum)
  • Sarah’s thoughts on improv inspired me to try it - hope to do it at RC soon
  • Juliano’s description on physiology of singing was cut short, would love to hear more about it (workshop anyone?)
  • Isabel’s presentation on genome editing with CRISPR brought some hopes for the H+ enthusiast in me
  • Taylor guided us rapidly through literary theory
  • James shared some insights on jazz reharmonisation, which makes me want to learn to play guitar properly even more

I’ve had my own non-techical moment on The First 20 Hours book and I’m hoping on writing a proper blog post on it soon and start my first learning experiment next week.

entry.title: RC - day 31
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • taking some time off
  • asking for help when I needed it

Everything is great now.

Wednesday I had a health scare - I fainted on the subway and ended up in a hospital. Nothing much happened, apart from lightly hitting my head on the subway car.

The experience was really stressful because of the insurance. Instead of keeping my cool and being happy someone takes care of me, I was constantly trying to calculate if my travel insurance is going to cover it. That’s a very US experience.

What surprised me is that you get the bill for emergency care about 4-6 weeks after the incident and you actually get three bills:

  • one from the ambulance company, because the ambulances are privately owned
  • one from the hospital
  • one from the doctor that checks you up at the hospital

Altogether an ambulance ride, an ECG & a blood pressure check at the hospital and a two minute chat with the doctor can cost anything between $2.000 and $8.000. Good my insurance is for more than $30.000.

With the Airbnb problems and lack of productivity over the weekend, I felt lost and extremely stressed. Luckily, my loved ones and the RC community were there for me. I decided to take it slow.

entry.title: RC - day 30
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • having a talk with Nancy about my career goals
  • drafting a presentation on learning
  • refactoring my goals and plans

I’ve decided today needs to be a productive day, despite the stress with the Airbnb. Refocusing on growing helped a lot, as did a cold shower from a loved one.

I had a chat with Nancy about my career goals and decided on the next steps I’m going to take in order to improve my professional presence:

  • refactoring some of my older projects that I can quickly improve and use in my portfolio
  • writing long overdue blog posts for my official blog
  • working more on the GitBook, as it is a project with community values in mind
  • looking into remote work opportunities

I’ve also reread a book on acquiring new skills - First 20 Hours by Josh Kaufman - and I’m going to use the concepts to improve my learning over the next few weeks. I also want to have a short presentation on the topic, since it is a system of simple concepts that can be useful to others.

In terms of long-term goals, I’ve revised my bucket, project, learning and productive procrastination lists (I seem to love lists for some reason). I’ve changed some priorities and aligned them more with my programming skills.

entry.title: RC - day 29
entry.content:
Achievements:

  • check-in
  • keeping the meditation habit streak
  • warm-up in Python
  • getting in touch with Tom to switch apartments
  • getting in touch with Airbnb to cancel my reservation
  • reading some “Gödel, Escher, Bach” and Aaronovitch
  • getting my suitcase to RC

The Internet came back today in the afternoon. Oh, the joy!

I’ve finally got some peace of mind with the apartment situation. Got in touch with Tom and will be staying at his apartment till Oct 3rd. Got in touch with Airbnb and will get a full refund for the remainder of my stay. Got my suitcase to RC from Uptown.

The rest of the day was mostly about reading and chilling, since I didn’t even realise all the Airbnb stuff was so stressful.

The new chill room (Babbage) is perfect for reading and napping and reading some more.
